user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_set_enable:
static METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE(linux_irq_cntr,
				    0, MAX_IRQS,
				    NULL,
				    metal_linux_irq_set_enable, NULL,
				    irqs)
...
static unsigned long
irqs_enabled[metal_div_round_up(MAX_IRQS, METAL_BITS_PER_ULONG)]
...
static metal_mutex_t irq_lock
...
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
#define METAL_IRQ_ENABLE 1U
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the above fragments because they are runtime operations that may be executed but could be functionally removable depending on configuration or usage (possible dead code): logging calls (both the invalid-irq log and the notify-failure log) can be no-ops when the log handler is absent or disabled; the notify call and its error-check/logging may be redundant if the notify file descriptor is unused or always fails/succeeds; the bitmap set/clear and the mutex acquire/release around them should be checked to confirm the bitmap and lock are actually required (if the bitmap is never read elsewhere or the lock is never needed those calls would be dead). I did NOT mark other fragments for investigation because they are clearly exercised or required for correct behaviour: the range check (if (irq < ... || irq >= ...)) is an active runtime validation (not to be treated as dead code and, per MISRA note, unreachable code is not the same as dead code); the offset computation (offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base) is used by the bitmap operations; the METAL_IRQ_ENABLE macro is used in the state comparison; variable declarations (offset, irq, state) and the function signature are necessary. In short, I focused on operations whose removal might not change program behaviour (logging, notify, bitmap and locking) and excluded obvious, required control-flow and data computations from further investigation.
